Maximum Height: This hybrid species is a rounded, spreading, multi-stemmed shrub and can grow up to about 1 - 2 m tall and 2 - 4 m wide.
Leaf Texture: Ovate leaves, dark green, glossy, opposite and simple, measuring about 2 - 5 cm long.
Leaves are yellow and green, elliptical in shape.
Leaves are variegated of yellow and green with a tinge of orange on the younger flushes, leaf blade is elliptical in shape, with crenate margin. Leaves are sometimes whorled or oppositely arranged.
Leaves velvety, palmately lobed.

Maximum Height: Large, mostly herbaceous plant with woody stem near the base up to 1.8 m or more tall.
Leaf Texture: Large, palmate leaves are deeply lobed with a toothed leaf margin.

Simple, palmately lobed leaves have an irregular, toothed leaf margin. The leaf blade bulges between veins, creating a bumpy, uneven surface. The petiole is long, cylindrical and sparsely covered in soft, white hairs.

The leaves are large, 15-30 cm in diameter, palmate-shaped with 5-9 lobes. The lobes are oblong to lanceolate shaped and sometimes pinnately lobed, measuring 8-18 cm long and 1-6 cm wide. The petiole is 6-18 cm long, stipules linear-lanceolate, sometimes there are 2 on each side of petiole, measuring 1-1.5 cm long. Leaf margin is obtusely serrated.

Maximum Height: Trailing herb up to 2 m across and 1.5 m tall.
Leaf Texture: Its stalked leaves are alternate, hairy and heart-shaped to 3-5 lobed, up to 15 cm long, with toothed margins.

The leaves are exist in two forms, lobed and unlobed. The lobed form has longer petiole (10-40cm), 3-5 lobed blade, cordate-ovate shape and irregularly dentate margin while unlobed form has shorter petiole (1-2cm), lance shaped blade and dentate margin.

Maximum Height: Abrus precatorius is a slender, perennial climber that twines around trees, shrubs and hedges. It has no special organs of attachment.

Leaf Texture: Dark green, palmately-lobed leaves.

Leaves simple, circular-ovate or heart-shaped, 5-12cm long and wide; both sides softly velvety-pubescent, alternately arranged, with coarsely crenate-serrate margins. Petiole 2-4cm, stipules subulate, 1-2mm, curved outward.

Foliage is variegated with green and yellow due to the Abutilon mosaic virus which is harmless to humans. Leaf blades palmate-shaped, 3 - 5 lobes, measuring 5 - 8 cm, smooth, margin dentate or serrate, apex acuminate; stipules subulate, caducous; petiole measuring 3 - 5 cm, smooth, hairless.
Green palmately-lobed leaves with cream-white margin.

Scientific Name: Acacia auriculiformis A. Cunn. ex Benth.
Leaf Texture: None
None

Native habitat: Terrestrial (Coastal Forest, Riverine, Grassland / Savannah/ Scrubland), Shoreline (Mangrove Forest)
Trunk Colour:
Greyish-brown to dark brown & slightly fissured in mature trees.
Greenish & smooth in young trees.
Leaf Texture: None
None

Maximum Height: Annual herb that grows up to 0.2 - 0.5 m tall.
Flower Colour: Flowers are arranged in hairy, oval-shaped inflorescences (1.5 - 3 cm long).
Leaf Texture: Leaves are deeply veined, ovate to lance-shaped with toothed leaf margin (3 - 6 cm long, 1.5 -3 cm wide).

Maximum Height: A herb, it has a prostrate and trailing growth form.
Leaf Texture: The leaves are ovate in shape and have a rounded base and acute apex and are held in opposie pairs along the stem. The leaves have a crenate-dentate margin, is covered with hairs and measure about 5 to 3.5 cm long and 1.5 cm wide.
Leaves simple, alternate, dark green, narrowly elliptic, with pink, wavy or toothed margins.
Simple, alternate leaves measuring about 10 - 20 cm long and 7 - 10 cm wide.
Egg-shaped leaves occur in a whorled leaf arrangement (3 or more leaves attached to the same point on the stem).

Maximum Height: Shrub, able to grow up to 2.5 m tall.
Leaf Texture: The leaves have a short petiole, pubescent, serrated along the margins, elliptic to obovate in shape, alternately arranged.

Maximum Height: Compact shrub, able to grow to about 1 - 2 m tall and 1 - 2 m wide.
Leaf Texture: Green leaves with patches of white, having a short petiole, serrated along the margins, elliptic to obovate in shape, alternately arranged,
Leaves are margined with cream-coloured lobes, large and broad leaf blades.

Maximum Height: Shrub which grows to about 2 - 3 m high and 2 m wide
Leaf Texture: Bright yellow to light green foliage with irregular splashes of green

Maximum Height: It is a spreading and erect shrub growing up to 2 - 3 m.
Leaf Texture: Leaves are large, round palmate-like leaves with serrated margin, coppery-bronze to green in colour.

Maximum Height: Erect or spreading shrub, up to 2 m tall.
Flower Colour: Flowers are borne on spikes, usually measuring about 10 - 20 cm long.
Leaf Texture: Large and broad leaves with toothed edges, measuring about 10 - 20 cm long and 15 - 20 cm wide.

Oblong, lobed leaves have sharp spines along the leaf margin. Smooth, shiny leaves have a variegated pattern of mostly green with white to cream-coloured patches concentrated mostly along the leaf margin, but sometimes covering more than half the leaf.

Its opposite, stalked
leaves have leaf blades that are oblong to oval, with toothed leaves that are
deeply lobed with spine tips along the leaf margin, shiny dark green above,
dark green below, and 7.5–20 by 2.5–6.5 cm.
Its opposite, shortly-stalked leaves possess spiny leaf blades that are oval to oblong, pale green with a yellowish tinge above and green below, and 5–22 cm by 2–7 cm.
The glossy, dark green leaves are large up to 0.6 m long. They are deeply lobed and soft-spiny, growing near the base of the plant.

Maximum Height: Semi-erect to climbing plant, has thin, dark-green, smooth stems, 4 - 8 m in height.
Leaf Texture: Leaf blades are smooth, entire or slightly lobed, usually without spines, fleshy to leathery, oblong-lanceolate, measuring 2.5 - 5 by 7 - 9 cm and have a blunt tip. Simple, opposite leaves with a leaf stalk about 1.0 cm long, slightly flattened and green.
The leaves are bipinnatified, the segments very finely cut, fern like, giving the leaves a feathery appearance.

Maximum Height: It is a rhizomatous herb that produces flowers in abundance (floriferous), measuring up to 30 cm in height. It often form horizontal shoots (semi prostrate) as the growing season progresses
Leaf Texture: Its leaves are dark green in colour, up to 3 cm long. Leaves are covered in sparse hairs and have a toothed margin.

Maximum Height: It is a hairy rhizomatous herb that produces flowers in abundance (floriferous), measuring up to 30 cm in height.
Leaf Texture: Its leaves are olive green with pale red underside measuring up to 3 cm long. The leaves are covered in sparse hairs and have a toothed margin.

Water Preference: Lots of Water, Moderate Water, Occasional Misting
Maximum Height: It is a rhizomatous herb that produces flowers in abundance (floriferous), measuring up to 30 cm in height.
Leaf Texture: Its leaves are dark green in colour, up to 3 cm long. Leaves are covered in sparse hairs and have a toothed margin.
Green, papery leaves (1.5-7 cm long, 0.4-4 cm wide) are broadly obovate (egg-shaped) or elliptic-oblong (oval-elongated). They are hairy on both sides.
Leaves are egg-shaped to triangular with a toothed leaf margin (5-11 cm long, 4-8 cm wide).
Leaves are egg- or lance-shaped with a toothed leaf margin and rough surface on both sides.
Leaves are lanceolate or narrowly ovate.

Maximum Height: A compact, low-growing shrub able to grow up to 2 - 5 m tall.
Leaf Texture: The leaves are green with an entire margin, an acuminate apex and a conspicuous midrib. The petioles are pink in colour. The young leaves are red in colour.

Flower Colour: The flowers are bisexual and consist of 6 tepals, 6 stamens and a sessile stigma.
Leaf Texture: None

Maximum Height: A sympodial epiphyte, it has a clumping growth form.
Leaf Texture: The pseudobulbs are oblong-ovoid in shape, each bearing 2 to 3 leaves. The leaves are narrow-oblong in shape and measure 7 to 7.5 cm long and 0.3 to 0.4 cm wide.

Maximum Height: A sympodial epiphyte, it has a clumping growth form.
Leaf Texture: The pseudobulbs each bear 2 leaves that are small and elliptic in shape.

Native habitat: Aquatic (Brackish Pond / Lake / River), Shoreline (Mangrove Forest)
Leaf Texture: Dark green, erect fronds are composed of 24 - 30 pinnae (leaflet-like structure) in alternate arrangement (1 - 4 m long, 0.12 - 0.5 m wide). The petiole of the frond (known as the stipe) is usually about 1 m long. The 5 - 8 pairs of pinnae near the tip are fertile with their underside covered in reddish brown sporangia (except the midrib), while the remaining pinnae are infertile. The pinnae are oblong with a blunt tip (8 - 50 cm long, 1 - 7 cm wide) and bright red when immature.

Large fronds are pinnately compound (up to 2 m long). The opposite pinnae are oblong with a sharply pointed tip (15 cm long). The fertile pinnae are smaller than the sterile ones and form dark brown sporangia that cover the entire underside.

Mature leaves large (up to 16cm long), thick, distinctly and numerously veined, with tomentose abadxial nerves and toothed margins. Either totally green or variegated with a central feather-shaped silvery-grey stripe. Young leaves soft, densely tomentose on both surfaces, emerging reddish and aging to coppery and light green. Leaves crowded along short internodes, giving plant a rosette appearance.
None
None

Maximum Height: It is a tall solitary palm, up to 15m tall. Trunk is marked with leaf scars and presence of a large cluster of roots at the base.
Flower Colour: Inflorescence is highly branched and consist of both male and female flowers (monoecious). Male flowers are asymmetrical in bud. Female flowers are globular, much larger than male flowers at maturity.
Leaf Texture: None

Native habitat: Terrestrial (Primary Rainforest, Secondary Rainforest, Coastal Forest, Disturbed Area / Open Ground)
Leaf Texture:
Its fronds (leaves) are erect,
grass-like, 20–35 cm by 2–3.5 cm, with a prominent midrib, and bearing at the
apex a digitate group of up to 18 fertile lobes, 2.5–4 cm by 1 mm.

Maximum Height: Large tree with a trunk that has an enormous girth, able to grow up to about 10 - 25 m tall.
Trunk Texture: Girth size usually between 3 - 10 m, but sometimes can reach up to 28 m wide. Bark is thick and fibrous and resistant to fire, termites and drought.
Trunk Colour: Girth size usually between 3 - 10 m, but sometimes can reach up to 28 m wide. Bark is thick and fibrous and resistant to fire, termites and drought.
Leaf Texture: None
None

Attracted Animals: Bird-Attracting, Butterfly Host Plant (Associated with: Polyura hebe plautus (Fruhstorfer, 1898))
Native habitat: Terrestrial (Primary Rainforest, Secondary Rainforest, Coastal Forest)
Leaf Texture: None
Round to heart-shaped leaves (9 cm long, 7.5 cm wide) have 2 glands at the base of the leaf blade. The tendrils are 5-7 cm long.

Its alternate, stalked leaves have thickly leathery blades that are usually oblong to lanceolate-shaped, and 5–15 by 1.8–8 cm, with two spoon-shaped glands at either side of the base, whitish green on the underside of the leaves. Leaf tip acute to acuminate, leaf base acute to rounded,
Smooth, glossy green leaves are obovate with entire leaf margin and truncate or rounded leaf apex. Leaves are spirally arranged.

Maximum Height: Herbaceous plant with a creeping growth habit.
Flower Colour: Light red flowers occur singly in the leaf axils (the space between the leaf and stem).
Leaf Texture: Leaves are ovate (0.6 - 2.5 cm long, 0.4 - 1.5 cm wide).

Maximum Height: Small to medium-sized fern, able to grow up to 40 - 50 cm tall and with a spread of 30 - 50 cm wide.
Leaf Texture: Dark green fronds are bipinnate to tripinnate, lamina reaching about 20 - 30 cm long; each frond is divided into 6 - 10 pinnae, (middle pinna usually the longest), and each pinna usually has 20 - 30 pairs of pinnules; sori usually 6 - 14 on the undersides of each pinnule, dark brown false indusia; stipe dark brown and measures about 20 cm long.

Maximum Height: Terrestrial fern to 20cm tall. forming dense stands where growing conditions are ideal.
Leaf Texture: Fronds to 30cm in length, mid green, in younger specimens often pinnate, with the lamina becoming bipinnate at base and simple pinnate at the apex in mature specimens. Juvenile fronds with a pale reddish flush. Sori oblong, on upper edge and distal half of the lower edge of the pinnae.

Each pinna holds a glossy green pinnule (leaflet) that is trapezoid (diamond-shaped). The two margins of the leaflet leading away from the pinna are smooth, whilst the two margins leading towards the apex are crenate. The entire fronds arch gracefully.

Petioles are glabrous, dark reddish, in bundles approximately 9.5-33cm in length, scales present at the base. Fronds are tripinnate, measuring 9.5-33 × 4.5-22cm. 7-13 pairs of leaflets, fan-shaped, light green but darkens with age. Leaflets have a cuneate base, rounded and wavy margin. It measures up to 1cm wide. Numerous spore cases, very small in size surrounded by a pale or whitish kidney-shaped membrane.

Flower Colour: Its flowers are arranged in 1.5–4.5 cm clusters and each has 5 corolla lobes that are 0.5 mm long, covered sparsely with hair.
Leaf Texture: None

Native habitat: Terrestrial (Secondary Rainforest, Disturbed Area / Open Ground)
Leaf Texture: None
None

Flower Colour: Inflorescence occurs outside the leaves, and branches up to 4 orders. It is 75 – 90 cm long, glabrous, white to pale green colour, and comprises of both male and female flowers. Male flower has 25 – 35 stamens, and mature before the female flowers. Female flower has 2 or 3 stigmas which are recurved at anthesis.
Trunk Texture: Stem is ringed with leaf scars, without vertical-wavy striations across internodes. Crownshaft is pale green to yellow-green.
Trunk Colour: Stem is ringed with leaf scars, without vertical-wavy striations across internodes. Crownshaft is pale green to yellow-green.
Leaf Texture: None
None

Maximum Height: A herbaceous shrub with a rosette growth form.
Leaf Texture: The most notable characteristic of this plant is the brilliant orange leaves. The leaves are arranged in a tight rosette form, stiff and edged with small spines.

Maximum Height: Aechmea chantinii is a herbaceous plant with a rosette growth form.
Leaf Texture: The leaves of Aechmea chantinii are green with silver strips, stiff, edged with many small spines.

Maximum Height: An epiphyte, it has a clumping growth form.
Leaf Texture: The leaves are elliptic in shape, silver-green in colour and arranged in a rosette. The leaf margins have black spines.

Maximum Height: A herbaceous plant with a rosette growth form.
Leaf Texture: The upperside of the leaf (adaxial surface) is green, while the underside (abaxial surface) is purplish colored. Leaves are stiff, edged with small spines.

Maximum Height: A herbaceous shrub with a rosette growth form.
Leaf Texture: Leaves are arranged in a rosette form, spineless, green with creamy-white strips on edges.

Maximum Height: An epiphyte, it has a clumping growth form.
Leaf Texture: The leaves are soft, green and arranged in a rosette.

Flower Colour: The flower inflorescence is 30 to 40cm in length with sessile, sub-erect flowers.
Leaf Texture: The simple leaves are arranged in a rosette and are ligulate and broadly acute. The leaf margins are covered with dark, serrated spines up to 5mm long.

Maximum Height: A herbaceous shrub with a rosette growth form.
Leaf Texture: Leaves are green, purple to burgundy-colored, arranged in a rosette form, stiff and edged with small spines.

Maximum Height: A herbaceous shrub grows over 1.2 m in diameter, with a rosette growth form.
Leaf Texture: Leaf blades are green and broad, and the leaf petioles are red and spiny. The foliage will develop red color in high light.
None

Maximum Height: Moderate sized tree up to 15 m tall.
Trunk Texture: Trunk is thick, and covered with soft, flaking bark. Branches are sometimes spiny and young suckers have many stiff, straight spines.
Trunk Colour: Trunk is thick, and covered with soft, flaking bark. Branches are sometimes spiny and young suckers have many stiff, straight spines.
Leaf Texture: None
None

Maximum Height: A monopodial, epiphytic orchid, it is endemic to the Philippines.
Flower Colour: The flower inflorescence is a raceme and dense with pendulous, arching growth habit. The purple and white flowers are long lasting and fragrant. The petals and sepals are white with purple tips while the spur is green.
Leaf Texture: The leaves are large and strap shaped.

Maximum Height: A stout, epiphytic orchid. It has a drooping, slightly pendulous growth form.
Leaf Texture: The leaves are obtuse and unequally bilobed.

Water Preference: Little Water, Moderate Water, Occasional Misting
Maximum Height: It is a slender, erect epiphyte.
Leaf Texture: Its opposite, shortly stalked leaves are fleshy, lance shaped or lens shape with a pointed tip, dull green on the topside and purple on the underside, 7.6 - 10.2 cm long by 2.5 - 3.8 cm wide.

Maximum Height: Shrubby epiphyte with stems to 40cm in length
Leaf Texture: Leaves leathery, veins indistinct. Upper surface of leaves dark green with light green markings, under surface with purplish red - dark maroon mottling.

Thick, fleshy leaves are elliptic or ovate with smooth leaf edges. They are oppositely arranged in pairs along long trailing stems. Leaves are smooth on the upper surface, with rarely sparsely pubescent on the undersides. Petiole 1-3 (sometimes up to 6) mm long. Leaf blades are dark green to purple, apex rounded to acuminate, base subcordate to cuneate.

Thick, fleshy leaves are elliptic and tightly curled under. They occur in decussate leaf arrangement with adjacent leaf pairs perpendicular to one another. The upper surface is smooth and dark green with a prominent sunken midrib, while the lower surface is light green.
Leaves green, thick leathery.

Oppositely arranged, petiole is 5 - 12 mm long and smooth. Leaves are thick and leathery, ovate to elliptic, measuring 3 - 10 long by 0.8 - 5 cm wide. Leaf blade has acuminate apex and cuneate to subcordate base, entire leaf edges, smooth on both surfaces.

Leaves odd-pinnately compound, with 11 opposite leaflets per leaf. Leaflets broadly-oval (7.5cm by 4.3 cm), soft, densely pubescent on both surfaces and along margins, appearing silvery-green on top and pale green below. Young leaflets densely furry, appearing silver-white before unfolding, produced on tomentose twining stems.

Leaves odd-pinnately compound, with 7-9 pairs of oblong to lanceolate leaflets arranged oppositely. Leaflets are 6.5cm by 2.5 cm, soft, green on top and pale green below, pubescent on both surfaces (more dense on the lower surface) and along margins. Young leaflets densely furry, appearing silver-white before unfolding, produced on tomentose twining stems.

Maximum Height: It is a shrub, or sometimes taking the form of a woody climber.
Native habitat: Terrestrial (Coastal Forest), Shoreline (Mangrove Forest, Sandy Beach)
Leaf Texture:
Its spirally
arranged, stalked, imparipinnate leaves have 3, 5, 7 or 9 leathery leaflets
whose blades are egg-shaped to egg-shaped-oblong, hairless, and 10–12.5 by 5–7.5
cm.
